stem: Which anatomical structure prevents backflow of blood into the left atrium during ventricular systole?
rationale: The mitral (bicuspid) valve separates the left atrium and ventricle and closes during systole to prevent regurgitation.

stem: Which anatomical components are part of the peripheral nervous system? (Select all that apply.)
rationale: The PNS consists of nerves and ganglia outside the brain and spinal cord.

stem: Which anatomical structure anchors skeletal muscle to bone?
rationale: Tendons transmit force from muscle contraction to bone, enabling movement.

stem: Complete the NGN bowtie using the anatomical case.
rationale: Damage to intestinal villi reduces surface area, impairing absorption of nutrients and leading to malnutrition.

tabs.case_study: Client with chronic alcohol use and malnutrition

stem: Which anatomical structure receives filtrate directly from the glomerulus?
rationale: Filtrate enters the proximal tubule immediately after glomerular filtration.

stem: Which hormones are produced by the anterior pituitary gland? (Select all that apply.)
rationale: Oxytocin and ADH are released from the posterior pituitary; the others are anterior pituitary hormones.

stem: Which anatomical structure is the primary site of gas exchange?
rationale: Alveoli provide a thin membrane and extensive surface area for diffusion of oxygen and carbon dioxide.

stem: Complete the NGN bowtie using the anatomical case.
rationale: The cerebellum fine-tunes motor activity and balance; lesions cause ataxia and tremor.

tabs.case_study: Client with loss of balance and intention tremor

stem: Which skin structure is responsible for thermoregulation through sweat production?
rationale: Eccrine glands secrete sweat directly onto the skin surface for cooling.

stem: Which anatomical structures transport sperm from the testes? (Select all that apply.)
rationale: Sperm mature in the epididymis, travel through the vas deferens, and exit via the urethra. ðŸ§  ANATOMY â€“ BATCH 8 (Questions 176â€“200) Same standards. No shortcuts. No repetition.

stem: Which anatomical structure allows blood to pass from the right atrium to the right ventricle?
rationale: The tricuspid valve separates the right atrium and right ventricle and prevents backflow during systole.

stem: Which anatomical functions are associated with the liver? (Select all that apply.)
rationale: The liver produces bile, stores glycogen, and detoxifies substances. Mechanical digestion occurs in the stomach; vitamin D is synthesized in skin.

stem: Which anatomical lobe of the brain is primarily responsible for visual processing?
rationale: The occipital lobe contains the primary visual cortex.

stem: Complete the NGN bowtie using the anatomical case.
rationale: Asbestos exposure causes fibrotic thickening of pleura, restricting lung expansion.

stem: Which bone forms the lateral aspect of the ankle joint?
rationale: The distal fibula forms the lateral malleolus of the ankle.

stem: Which anatomical features are associated with diabetes mellitus type 1? (Select all that apply.)
rationale: Type 1 diabetes involves autoimmune destruction of beta cells, reducing insulin production.

stem: Which anatomical structure concentrates urine via osmotic gradient?
rationale: The loop of Henle establishes the medullary osmotic gradient necessary for urine concentration.

stem: Complete the bowtie using the neurological case.
rationale: Basal ganglia dysfunction impairs initiation and modulation of voluntary movement.

tabs.case_study: Client with inability to initiate voluntary movement

stem: Which layer of the skin is responsible for waterproofing?
rationale: The stratum corneum contains keratin and lipids that prevent water loss.

stem: Which anatomical changes occur in the testes during puberty? (Select all that apply.)
rationale: Puberty triggers testicular growth, sperm production, and scrotal skin thickening. ðŸ§  ANATOMY â€“ BATCH 7 (Questions 151â€“175) Same rules. No drift. No shortcuts.

stem: Which coronary artery supplies the right atrium and right ventricle?
rationale: The right coronary artery supplies the right atrium, right ventricle, and often the SA and AV nodes.

stem: Which anatomical features distinguish the large intestine from the small intestine? (Select all that apply.)
rationale: The large intestine contains haustra and teniae coli and hosts extensive microbiota; villi and plicae circulares belong to the small intestine.

stem: Which structure connects the hypothalamus to the pituitary gland?
rationale: The infundibulum (pituitary stalk) links the hypothalamus to the pituitary, allowing hormonal control.

stem: Complete the NGN bowtie using the anatomical case.
rationale: Chronic hypoxia stimulates capillary growth to enhance oxygen delivery at the alveolar level.

tabs.case_study: Client with prolonged hypoxia at high altitude

stem: Which muscle is primarily responsible for elbow flexion?
rationale: The biceps brachii flexes the elbow and supinates the forearm.

stem: Which anatomical effects occur in hyperthyroidism? (Select all that apply.)
rationale: Excess thyroid hormone accelerates metabolism, increases heat production, and causes gland enlargement.

stem: Which structure forms the filtration barrier within the renal corpuscle?
rationale: Podocytes form filtration slits that regulate passage of substances from blood into Bowmanâ€™s space.

stem: Complete the bowtie using the neurological case.
rationale: Loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra produces Parkinsonian motor deficits.

tabs.case_study: Client with resting tremor and rigidity

stem: Which skin structure produces sebum?
rationale: Sebaceous glands secrete sebum to lubricate and protect skin and hair.

stem: Which anatomical changes occur in the cervix during labor? (Select all that apply.)
rationale: Labor involves cervical thinning, shortening, and dilation; collagen softens rather than increases. ðŸ§  ANATOMY â€“ BATCH 6 (Questions 126â€“150) Standards unchanged Anatomy-only Difficulty 3 / 4 / 5 Anatomy.json structure High stem/choice diversity Coherent bowties with real case tabs

stem: Which anatomical structure prevents backflow of blood from the aorta into the left ventricle?
rationale: The aortic valve closes during diastole to prevent regurgitation into the left ventricle.

stem: Which anatomical components are part of the enteric nervous system? (Select all that apply.)
rationale: The enteric nervous system consists of intrinsic plexuses within the GI wall controlling motility and secretion.

stem: Which structure connects the cerebellum to the brainstem?
rationale: Superior, middle, and inferior cerebellar peduncles connect the cerebellum to the brainstem.

stem: Complete the NGN bowtie using the anatomical endocrine case.
rationale: Primary adrenal insufficiency (Addison disease) results from cortical destruction, leading to cortisol deficiency and adrenal atrophy.

stem: Which bone is classified as a sesamoid bone?
rationale: Sesamoid bones form within tendons; the patella improves leverage of the quadriceps tendon.

stem: Which anatomical changes occur during pulmonary fibrosis? (Select all that apply.)
rationale: Fibrosis stiffens lung tissue, thickens alveoli, and increases recoil, impairing gas exchange.

stem: Which anatomical structure drains urine from the kidney into the ureter?
rationale: The renal pelvis funnels urine from calyces into the ureter.

stem: Complete the bowtie using the neurological injury case.
rationale: Lesions of the subthalamic nucleus cause hemiballismus with violent involuntary movements.

stem: Which cells are responsible for immune defense in the epidermis?
rationale: Langerhans cells are antigen-presenting immune cells within the epidermis.

stem: Which anatomical changes occur in the uterus during pregnancy? (Select all that apply.)
rationale: Pregnancy causes uterine muscle growth, vascular expansion, and cavity enlargement to support fetal development. ðŸ§  ANATOMY â€“ BATCH 5 (Questions 101â€“125) Same standards, no drift: Anatomy-only Difficulty 3 / 4 / 5 anatomy.json structure Strong stem diversity Coherent bowties with real case tabs No recycled logic or answers

stem: Which anatomical structure is responsible for regulating circadian rhythm?
rationale: The pineal gland secretes melatonin, which regulates sleepâ€“wake cycles and circadian rhythm.

stem: Which anatomical features contribute to venous return to the heart? (Select all that apply.)
rationale: Venous return relies on valves, muscle contraction, and respiratory pressure changes. Thick tunica media and arterial pressure are arterial features.

stem: Which anatomical structure connects the oral cavity to the esophagus?
rationale: The pharynx serves as a shared passageway for food and air, directing boluses toward the esophagus.

stem: Complete the NGN bowtie using the anatomical case.
rationale: Chronic hypertension damages glomeruli, reducing filtration capacity and thickening the basement membrane.

tabs.case_study: Client with long-standing hypertension and declining renal function

stem: Which bone articulates with the femur at the knee joint?
rationale: The tibia forms the primary weight-bearing articulation with the femur at the knee.

stem: Which anatomical effects result from excess cortisol? (Select all that apply.)
rationale: Cortisol promotes protein breakdown, bone loss, and fat redistribution.

stem: Which structure marks the anatomical division between the upper and lower respiratory tract?
rationale: The larynx separates the upper airway from the lower conducting structures.

stem: Complete the bowtie using the anatomical wound case.
rationale: Stage 4 pressure injuries extend through skin into muscle, compromising structural integrity.

stem: Which structure transports sperm from the epididymis to the urethra?
rationale: The vas deferens carries mature sperm during ejaculation.

stem: Which functions are associated with the parietal lobe? (Select all that apply.)
rationale: The parietal lobe processes somatosensory input and spatial orientation. ðŸ§  ANATOMY â€“ BATCH 4 (Questions 76â€“100) Standards maintained Anatomy-only (no nursing process) Difficulty 3â€“5 Anatomy.json structure Strong stem & answer diversity Bowties with coherent anatomy + real case tabs

stem: Which anatomical layer of the heart is responsible for contraction?
rationale: The myocardium contains cardiac muscle fibers that generate the force required for pumping blood.

stem: Which anatomical structures contribute to bile production and storage? (Select all that apply.)
rationale: Bile is produced by hepatocytes, stored in the gallbladder, and transported via bile ducts. Pancreatic acini produce enzymes; Kupffer cells are macrophages.

stem: Which structure serves as the primary relay station for sensory information to the cerebral cortex?
rationale: The thalamus relays nearly all sensory input to the appropriate cortical regions.

stem: Complete the NGN bowtie using the anatomical case.
rationale: Asthma causes reversible bronchoconstriction due to smooth muscle tightening and mucosal edema, increasing airway resistance.

tabs.case_study: Client with chronic asthma and wheezing

stem: Which bone forms the posterior portion of the hard palate?
rationale: The palatine bones form the posterior hard palate and part of the nasal cavity.

stem: Which hormones are produced by the adrenal cortex? (Select all that apply.)
rationale: The adrenal cortex produces mineralocorticoids, glucocorticoids, and androgens. Catecholamines come from the medulla.

stem: Which anatomical structure prevents backflow of urine from the bladder into the ureters?
rationale: The oblique insertion of the ureters into the bladder wall forms a functional valve.

stem: Complete the bowtie using the case information.
rationale: Cerebellar damage disrupts coordination and fine motor control, producing dysmetria and ataxia.

tabs.case_study: Client with intention tremor and ataxia

stem: Which structure anchors the skin to underlying tissues?
rationale: The hypodermis contains adipose and connective tissue that secures skin to deeper structures.

stem: Which anatomical changes occur during puberty in males? (Select all that apply.)
rationale: Puberty involves gonadal maturation, androgen surge, and skeletal growth plate closure. ðŸ§  ANATOMY â€“ BATCH 3 (25 Questions)

stem: Which anatomical structure directly connects the two cerebral hemispheres?
rationale: The corpus callosum is a dense band of commissural fibers allowing communication between the left and right hemispheres.

stem: Which anatomical features are characteristics of skeletal muscle tissue? (Select all that apply.)
rationale: Skeletal muscle is voluntary, striated, and multinucleated. Intercalated discs are cardiac; spindle shape describes smooth muscle.

stem: Which vessel carries oxygenated blood from the lungs to the heart?
rationale: Pulmonary veins uniquely carry oxygenated blood from the lungs to the left atrium.

stem: Complete the NGN bowtie using the anatomical case.
rationale: Villi dramatically increase absorptive area. Their destruction leads to malabsorption and a smooth intestinal lining.

tabs.case_study: Client with chronic malabsorption and weight loss

stem: Which gland secretes parathyroid hormone?
rationale: Parathyroid glands regulate calcium via parathyroid hormone (PTH).

stem: Which anatomical changes are seen in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease? (Select all that apply.)
rationale: COPD involves emphysematous alveolar destruction and chronic bronchial inflammation, reducing elastic recoil.

stem: Which renal structure receives blood directly from the afferent arteriole?
rationale: The afferent arteriole delivers blood to the glomerular capillary tuft for filtration.

stem: Complete the bowtie using the anatomical injury case.
rationale: Full-thickness burns destroy dermal nerves, resulting in painless, dry, rigid tissue.

tabs.case_study: Third-degree burn with painless, dry wound

stem: Which structure produces testosterone?
rationale: Leydig cells in the testes secrete testosterone.

stem: Which functions are associated with the frontal lobe? (Select all that apply.)
rationale: The frontal lobe governs motor activity, reasoning, and expressive language (Brocaâ€™s area). ðŸ§  ANATOMY â€“ BATCH 2 (Next 25 Questions) Same rules upheld: Anatomy-only (no nursing interventions) Difficulty 3â€“5 only Structured exactly like the working anatomy JSON Strong variation in: Stem logic Answer choices Bowtie anatomy causality Includes single, SATA, and bowtie Bowties include real case tabs and anatomically correct linkages

stem: Which anatomical structure separates the left atrium from the left ventricle?
rationale: The mitral (bicuspid) valve lies between the left atrium and left ventricle, regulating blood flow during diastole and systole.

stem: Which anatomical structures increase surface area for nutrient absorption in the small intestine? (Select all that apply.)
rationale: These three structures exponentially increase absorptive surface area. Rugae are gastric; teniae coli are in the colon.

stem: Which part of the brainstem regulates respiratory rhythm?
rationale: The pons modulates respiratory rhythm via pontine respiratory centers that coordinate inspiration and expiration.

stem: Complete the NGN bowtie using the anatomical case.
rationale: ADH acts on the collecting duct, inserting aquaporins to conserve water during dehydration.

stem: Which type of joint allows the greatest range of motion?
rationale: Ball-and-socket joints (e.g., shoulder, hip) allow flexion, extension, rotation, abduction, and adduction.

stem: Which anatomical features distinguish the posterior pituitary? (Select all that apply.)
rationale: The posterior pituitary is neural tissue and storesâ€”not producesâ€”hypothalamic hormones.

stem: Which anatomical structure prevents food from entering the trachea during swallowing?
rationale: The epiglottis folds over the laryngeal inlet during swallowing to protect the airway.

stem: Complete the bowtie using the case information.
rationale: Wernickeâ€™s area controls language comprehension. Damage results in fluent but meaningless speech.

stem: Which skin layer contains melanocytes?
rationale: Melanocytes reside in the basal layer and produce melanin for pigmentation and UV protection.

stem: Which anatomical structures are part of the cardiac conduction system? (Select all that apply.)
rationale: These structures generate and propagate electrical impulses. Papillary muscles are mechanical, not conductive. ðŸ§  ANATOMY â€“ BATCH 1 (25)

stem: A client sustains a mid-shaft humeral fracture. Which anatomical structure is at greatest risk for injury?
rationale: The radial nerve courses through the radial groove of the humerus, making it particularly vulnerable in mid-shaft humeral fractures. Injury may result in wrist drop.

stem: Which anatomical features contribute directly to one-way blood flow through the heart? (Select all that apply.)
rationale: AV valves prevent backflow; chordae tendineae and papillary muscles stabilize valve closure during ventricular contraction. The septum and coronary arteries do not regulate flow direction.

stem: Damage to which anatomical structure would most directly impair coordination and balance?
rationale: The cerebellum fine-tunes motor activity, posture, and balance. Injury results in ataxia, dysmetria, and coordination deficits.

stem: Complete the NGN bowtie using the anatomical case information.
rationale: Emphysema causes alveolar destruction, reducing surface area and elastic recoil. Pursed-lip breathing increases airway pressure and improves expiration.

tabs.case_study: Client with chronic smoking history presents with dyspnea and barrel chest
tabs.labs: Imaging: Flattened diaphragms on chest X-ray

stem: Which anatomical layer of the gastrointestinal tract is primarily responsible for peristalsis?
rationale: The muscularis externa contains circular and longitudinal smooth muscle layers that generate peristaltic movement.

stem: Which anatomical features are part of the hypothalamicâ€“pituitary axis? (Select all that apply.)
rationale: The infundibulum connects the hypothalamus to both lobes of the pituitary. The pineal gland and mammillary bodies are not part of the axis.

stem: Which nephron structure is primarily responsible for water reabsorption under the influence of ADH?
rationale: ADH increases aquaporin channels in the collecting duct, enhancing water reabsorption.

stem: Complete the bowtie using the anatomical injury case.
rationale: Partial-thickness burns spare some dermal structures like hair follicles but disrupt barrier integrity.

stem: Which anatomical structure is the site of fertilization?
rationale: Fertilization typically occurs in the ampulla of the fallopian tube.

stem: Which anatomical structures are part of the limbic system? (Select all that apply.)
rationale: The limbic system governs emotion and memory. The basal ganglia are motor-related; the thalamus is primarily a sensory relay.
